security: The President is obviously opposed to Lodge (his opposition goes back to conflicts in the Senate). He asked for recommendations as to who would be a good man and who could run the American team...The President then turned to Cuba. He asked how effective our policy was and what was the future of Cuba. He asked how effective the economic denial program was and how we planned to dispose of Castro.
summary: A collection of memoranda detailing President Johnson's meetings and briefings on various foreign policy issues including Cuba, Vietnam, Pakistan, and Soviet relations, as well as personnel matters and intelligence operations.
summary_one_paragraph: This compilation of memoranda captures President Lyndon B. Johnson's initial engagements on foreign policy and intelligence matters following President Kennedy's assassination. Covering discussions from late November through December 1963, the memos detail Johnson's concerns and directives on Cuba (including strategies for economic denial and Castro's removal), Vietnam (personnel changes, policy modifications, and public reaction), Pakistan (improving relationships with President Ayub), and the Multilateral Force (MLF). Additionally, they shed light on Johnson's interest in personnel appointments, including potential cabinet changes and ambassadorial selections, as well as his handling of intelligence operations and briefings during this transitional period.
title: Memoranda for the Record: Meetings with President Johnson on Cuba, Vietnam, Pakistan, and Other Foreign Policy Issues
persons_mentioned: Deputy Under Secretary U. Alexis Johnson
